unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: What does SIA stand for?

options.A: Security Industry Association
options.B: Security Industry Authority
options.C: Surveillance Industry Authority
options.D: Safety Industry Authority

explanation: SIA stands for Security Industry Authority. It is the statutory organisation that regulates the private security industry in the UK, including licensing CCTV (Public Space Surveillance) operators.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which Act of Parliament created the Security Industry Authority and the modern system for regulating the private security industry?

options.A: Private Security Industry Act 2001
options.B: Crime and Disorder Act 1998
options.C: Data Protection Act 2018
options.D: Criminal Justice Act 2003

explanation: The Private Security Industry Act 2001 created the Security Industry Authority and set the legal framework for regulating the private security industry in the UK. isova.co.uk

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: How long is a Public Space Surveillance (CCTV) SIA licence normally valid for?

options.A: 1 year
options.B: 2 years
options.C: 3 years
options.D: 5 years

explanation: Most SIA front line licences, including Public Space Surveillance (CCTV), are normally valid for 3 years before they must be renewed. Vehicle immobiliser licences are the main exception. Regulated Professions

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which ONE of the following situations definitely requires an SIA Public Space Surveillance (CCTV) licence?

options.A: A homeowner watching their own domestic CCTV cameras on a mobile phone.
options.B: A supermarket manager reviewing cameras covering only their own store, where all staff are employed directly by the supermarket.
options.C: A highways officer viewing motorway cameras to manage traffic flow.
options.D: A contracted CCTV operator in a town-centre control room, monitoring members of the public and directing police to incidents.

explanation: A CCTV licence is required where CCTV is used to guard premises, property or people by watching members of the public or identifying particular individuals, for example in a town‑centre control room monitoring public spaces and directing police. Domestic CCTV, purely in‑house retail CCTV and traffic monitoring are normally not licensable.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which of the following MUST appear on your SIA CCTV licence card?

options.A: A recent photograph of the licence holder
options.B: Your National Insurance number
options.C: Your bank sort code
options.D: A list of your previous employers

explanation: An SIA licence is a credit-card sized photocard showing the holder’s photograph, licence type and expiry date so that people can confirm that the person wearing it is the genuine, licensed operative.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which ONE of these jobs is regulated by the SIA and normally requires the holder to have an SIA licence?

options.A: Police constable
options.B: School teacher
options.C: Door supervisor at a nightclub
options.D: Taxi driver

explanation: Door supervision is one of the SIA’s licensable sectors, along with public space surveillance (CCTV), security guarding, close protection, cash and valuables in transit, vehicle immobilisation and key holding. Police officers and other public‑sector roles are regulated under different legal frameworks.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Working as a CCTV operator in a town‑centre control room without the correct SIA licence is:

options.A: Acceptable if your employer agrees
options.B: Only a breach of company policy, not the law
options.C: A civil matter with no criminal consequences
options.D: A criminal offence under the Private Security Industry Act 2001

explanation: It is a criminal offence to engage in licensable conduct (such as public space surveillance CCTV work under contract) without holding the appropriate SIA licence. On indictment, the maximum penalty can be up to 5 years’ imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: The SIA Approved Contractor Scheme (ACS) is mainly aimed at:

options.A: Individual CCTV operators
options.B: Private security companies who wish to demonstrate higher standards
options.C: Members of the public
options.D: Police forces

explanation: The Approved Contractor Scheme is a voluntary quality‑assurance scheme for private security companies, not for individual operatives. It allows companies to demonstrate they meet independently assessed standards above the legal minimum.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which of the following is an example of a sector within the private security industry regulated by the SIA?

options.A: Cash and valuables in transit
options.B: Firefighting for the local fire service
options.C: Providing medical treatment in a hospital A&E
options.D: Delivering letters for Royal Mail

explanation: Cash and Valuables in Transit (CVIT) is one of the SIA’s licensable activities, along with door supervision, public space surveillance (CCTV), close protection, security guarding, vehicle immobilisation and key holding.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: When you are working in a CCTV control room in a licensable role, what must you do with your SIA licence?

options.A: Lock it away in a locker so it cannot be seen
options.B: Leave it at home as long as your supervisor knows your licence number
options.C: Have it with you and display it so it can be seen unless there is a specific operational reason not to
options.D: Only bring it in if the police ask to see it

explanation: Front line SIA licences are issued as photocard badges that must be worn or kept with you while you are working, and must be produced on request by authorised persons. They are intended to be visible so that the public, employers and enforcement officers can confirm you are properly licensed.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Raj is employed directly by a national supermarket chain. His job is to sit in the back office and watch cameras that only cover the inside of his own store and staff‑only areas. Under normal circumstances, does he need an SIA Public Space Surveillance (CCTV) licence for this role?

options.A: Yes, because anyone who watches CCTV at work must have an SIA licence
options.B: No, because he is working in‑house for his own employer on their premises only
options.C: Yes, but only on Saturdays
options.D: No, because supermarket CCTV is never licensable, even for contracted staff

explanation: SIA guidance states that you do not usually need a licence when working in‑house (directly employed by the organisation that uses your services), such as a supermarket employing its own staff to monitor its own cameras. A licence is generally required where there is a contract for services and the work involves a licensable activity.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A security company supplies CCTV operators under contract to run a town‑centre control room. One operator’s SIA licence has expired but they are still put on shift to monitor cameras. Under the Private Security Industry Act 2001, what offence might the company be committing?

options.A: None, because the operator used to be licensed
options.B: Only the individual operator can commit an offence in this situation
options.C: Only the local authority client could be prosecuted
options.D: Employing an unlicensed person to carry out licensable activities, which is a criminal offence for the employer

explanation: As well as it being an offence for an individual to work without a licence, the Act also makes it an offence for an employer to engage or deploy unlicensed people in licensable roles. Both the company and the individual can face criminal proceedings. Mortons Solicitors

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Before you can apply to the SIA for a Public Space Surveillance (CCTV) licence, you must first:

options.A: Work at least 6 months as an unlicensed trainee in any CCTV control room
options.B: Complete a first-aid at work qualification
options.C: Achieve the Level 2 licence-linked qualification for CCTV operators with an approved training provider
options.D: Attend an SIA interview at your local police station

explanation: For a CCTV (Public Space Surveillance) licence you must complete the relevant Level 2 licence‑linked qualification with an SIA‑approved training provider before you apply. This is a legal requirement and covers Unit 1 (working in the private security industry), Unit 2 (working as a CCTV operator) and the practical use of CCTV systems.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which of the following is MOST likely to lead the SIA to refuse an application for a CCTV operator licence?

options.A: An unspent conviction for robbery and assault from two years ago
options.B: Having changed address twice in the last year
options.C: Not holding a full UK driving licence
options.D: Having previously worked in a non‑security job

explanation: The SIA carries out criminal record checks and looks particularly closely at offences involving violence, dishonesty and drugs when deciding if someone is fit and proper to hold a licence. Serious recent convictions for robbery and assault are very likely to cause a refusal, whereas changes of address or past non‑security employment are not usually barriers on their own. Agile Security Training

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A colleague in your CCTV control room uses their mobile phone to take a picture of a monitor showing a shoplifter and then shares it in a private WhatsApp group “for a laugh”. What is the MOST appropriate action for a professional CCTV operator?

options.A: Ignore it because the group is private
options.B: Join in and share the image with friends
options.C: Do nothing unless the person in the image complains
options.D: Challenge the behaviour and report it through your organisation’s procedures, as it risks breaching data protection, SIA standards and public trust

explanation: CCTV images are personal data and must be handled lawfully, fairly and for legitimate purposes. Taking photos of screens and sharing them informally is likely to breach data protection requirements, CCTV codes of practice and SIA expectations of professional conduct, and it seriously undermines public trust. The correct response is to challenge and report the misuse. IQ Verify

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which ONE of the following checks is always carried out as part of the SIA licensing process for CCTV operators?

options.A: A formal physical fitness test
options.B: A criminal record check (for example via the DBS) to look at relevant convictions
options.C: A driving test of your ability to drive patrol vehicles
options.D: A home visit by SIA staff

explanation: As part of the licence application, the SIA verifies identity, right to work and carries out a criminality check using official records (such as DBS information) before deciding whether to grant or refuse a licence. There is no routine fitness test or driving test for CCTV operators. Get Licensed

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: During a busy evening shift in the town‑centre control room, you realise you have left your SIA licence badge at home and cannot produce it if asked. What is the BEST action to take?

options.A: Carry on as normal – the licence number on the staff rota is enough
options.B: Hide in the back of the control room so nobody sees you
options.C: Inform your supervisor immediately and stop carrying out licensable duties until you can prove you hold a valid licence
options.D: Borrow a colleague’s licence as a temporary measure

explanation: Front line licence holders are required to have their licence with them and display it while carrying out licensable activities. If you cannot produce your badge, the safest option is to tell your supervisor and step away from licensable duties until your licence can be shown, rather than working un‑badged or (worse) using someone else’s licence.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A local authority is choosing between two security companies to run its CCTV control room. One of the companies is part of the SIA Approved Contractor Scheme (ACS). Why might the authority see this as an advantage?

options.A: ACS status shows the company has been independently assessed as meeting higher standards of management and service
options.B: ACS status means the company does not need to license its staff
options.C: ACS status guarantees the company is the cheapest
options.D: ACS status allows the company to ignore British Standards

explanation: ACS is a voluntary quality assurance scheme in which companies are independently assessed against recognised operational and performance standards. It is often viewed as a “quality mark” and can give buyers confidence in the professionalism and management systems of the security supplier. It does not remove the need to licence individual staff.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A member of the public asks why CCTV operators have to be licensed by the SIA at all. Which reply BEST explains the main purpose of SIA regulation?

options.A: To raise money through licence fees
options.B: To protect the public by ensuring security staff are properly vetted, trained and meet agreed standards
options.C: To remove the need for police officers in town centres
options.D: To promote private security companies’ profits

explanation: The SIA’s mission is to protect the public, reduce criminality and improve standards in the private security industry through licensing individuals and managing the ACS for companies. Licensing checks identity, criminality and qualification so that only suitable, trained people can work in sensitive roles such as public space CCTV. Compact Security

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: In a CCTV control room, you discover that a new operator is using a relative’s SIA badge because their own application has not yet been approved. Which statement is MOST accurate?

options.A: This is acceptable if both people have passed the training course
options.B: This is only a minor breach of company policy
options.C: This is allowed as long as their supervisor knows
options.D: This could amount to using a false licence and is a serious criminal matter that could lead to prosecution and loss of licensing

explanation: Using someone else’s licence misleads others into believing the wearer is the vetted and approved person named on the card. The Act creates offences around using false licences or falsely claiming status (for example ACS approval), and such conduct can lead to prosecution and the loss of any existing or future SIA licences. Mortons Solicitors

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Sam holds a valid SIA CCTV licence and works nights in a transport hub control room. Six months into the licence period he receives a conviction for a serious assault. Worried he might lose his job, he continues working and does not inform his employer or the SIA. Which of the following BEST describes Sam’s position?

options.A: He is safe to continue working because his licence is still within its three‑year expiry date
options.B: He only needs to tell the SIA when he next renews his licence
options.C: He is breaching his licence conditions because he must report relevant changes such as new criminal convictions, and this could lead to his licence being reviewed or revoked
options.D: He can avoid problems by applying for a second licence instead

explanation: SIA licence conditions require holders to tell the SIA about relevant changes, including new criminal convictions. Failure to do so is a breach of licence conditions and may lead to suspension or revocation if the SIA decides he is no longer fit and proper to hold a licence. Simply waiting until renewal does not meet his obligations.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Mia’s SIA CCTV licence card is lost on the way to work. She still holds a valid licence on the SIA’s system. What is the MOST appropriate first step she should take?

options.A: Report the loss to the SIA and apply for a replacement licence card as soon as possible
options.B: Borrow a colleague’s badge until the end of the week
options.C: Stop working permanently because she can never be issued another licence
options.D: Continue as normal and only mention it at her next renewal in two years

explanation: If a licence card is lost or stolen, the holder should inform the SIA promptly and request a replacement. A replacement card can be issued for a fee, and the licence record itself remains valid. Borrowing someone else’s card would be dishonest and could amount to using a false licence. portlandtraining.co.uk

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A CCTV operator is considering two job offers: one with a small security company that is not part of the ACS, and one with a larger firm that is an SIA Approved Contractor. From the operator’s point of view, which statement is MOST accurate?

options.A: Working for an ACS company means he personally does not need an SIA licence
options.B: ACS companies are regularly audited and usually offer better training and professional standards, which can support his career development
options.C: ACS companies are exempt from health and safety law
options.D: Non‑ACS companies are not allowed to operate CCTV control rooms at all

explanation: ACS‑approved companies are independently assessed against a wide range of criteria, including staff training, vetting, management systems and service delivery. This often means a more professional environment and better development opportunities for staff, but individuals still need their own SIA licences. NSI

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Your control room manager says the CCTV scheme is being reviewed to ensure it complies with BS 7958. What is the MAIN reason this is important for a public‑space CCTV system?

options.A: BS 7958 replaces the need for any SIA licensing
options.B: BS 7958 only deals with how many cameras a control room must have
options.C: BS 7958 gives recognised best‑practice recommendations for managing and operating CCTV control rooms, supporting evidence quality and protection of individuals’ rights
options.D: BS 7958 is a standard that only applies to static guarding patrols

explanation: BS 7958 is the British Standard that provides a code of practice for the management and operation of CCTV within a controlled environment, including public‑space systems. It focuses on good governance, evidential standards and respect for privacy and legal requirements. Static guarding and patrol services are instead covered by BS 7499. brunelmanagement.co.uk IQ Verify

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A contracted CCTV control room repeatedly ignores procedures, allows unlicensed staff to monitor cameras, and has several incidents where operators share images on social media. Which of the following is the MOST likely combination of consequences?

options.A: The police will automatically take over running the system with no further action
options.B: The operators might be told to attend extra training, but there are no legal or professional risks
options.C: Only the security company’s profits will be affected, with no impact on the wider industry
options.D: There could be loss of public trust, legal or regulatory action (for example under the Private Security Industry Act and data protection law), and individuals may lose their SIA licences

explanation: Persistent poor practice can lead to loss of public confidence, regulatory enforcement by the SIA (including inspections, warnings or prosecution) and potential breaches of data protection and human rights law. Individuals involved risk suspension or revocation of their licences, and the company may face criminal or civil action. unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which article of the Human Rights Act 1998 protects the right to respect for private life?

options.A: Article 5
options.B: Article 6
options.C: Article 8
options.D: Article 10

explanation: Article 8 of the Human Rights Act protects the right to respect for private and family life. For CCTV operators this is crucial, because surveillance must be necessary, proportionate and for a legitimate aim, and must always respect people’s privacy as far as possible.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: What is the main purpose of the Human Rights Act 1998?

options.A: To incorporate the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law
options.B: To create the Security Industry Authority and licence security staff
options.C: To replace all criminal law with civil law
options.D: To give CCTV operators special powers of arrest

explanation: The Human Rights Act 1998 brings the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law. This means people can rely on their Convention rights, such as privacy and fair trial, in UK courts and public authorities (including local authorities running CCTV) must respect those rights.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which article of the Human Rights Act prohibits torture and inhuman or degrading treatment, and is considered an absolute right?

options.A: Article 2
options.B: Article 3
options.C: Article 5
options.D: Article 10

explanation: Article 3 of the Human Rights Act prohibits torture and inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It is an absolute right, meaning it cannot be limited or interfered with under any circumstances. CCTV operators must always treat people with dignity and ensure that footage is not used in a way that degrades or humiliates individuals.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A CCTV operator monitoring a quiet car park at night sees a person collapse and lie motionless. Which action best reflects the Article 2 (right to life) duty?

options.A: Switch cameras because it might just be someone resting
options.B: Ignore it to avoid invading the person’s privacy
options.C: Continue recording but take no further action
options.D: Monitor the situation closely and promptly alert emergency services

explanation: Article 2 places a duty on public authorities to protect life where possible. Using CCTV to observe the situation and quickly contact emergency services helps protect the person’s life and is a proper use of surveillance.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which statement best describes how most Human Rights Act rights apply to CCTV use?

options.A: They can be limited if surveillance is necessary, proportionate and for a legitimate aim such as preventing crime
options.B: They never apply in public places because there is no privacy in public
options.C: They allow CCTV to monitor anyone, anywhere, for any reason
options.D: They can only be limited by a judge after a criminal trial

explanation: Most rights (such as Article 8 – private life) are qualified rights. They may be limited for legitimate purposes like national security or crime prevention, but only where the interference is necessary and proportionate. CCTV schemes must balance security needs with individuals’ rights.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which of the following is a legitimate aim that can justify limiting someone’s Article 8 right to private life through CCTV surveillance?

options.A: Increasing the shopping centre’s profits
options.B: Preventing and detecting crime in a town centre
options.C: Satisfying staff curiosity in the control room
options.D: Providing entertainment for operators during quiet periods

explanation: Crime prevention and detection is a recognised legitimate aim that can justify some interference with privacy. However, any interference must still be proportionate and properly controlled. Using CCTV for profit, curiosity or entertainment would not be lawful.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A camera overlooking a street can also zoom into the windows of nearby flats. A manager suggests keeping the camera permanently zoomed in “just in case something happens”. What should most concern the CCTV operator?

options.A: That the storage capacity won’t be big enough
options.B: That the camera’s picture quality might be too high
options.C: That constant viewing into people’s homes is unlikely to be necessary or proportionate under Article 8
options.D: That the police will have too much evidence to review

explanation: Article 8 requires respect for private life. Constantly zooming into private homes is unlikely to be necessary or proportionate. Cameras should normally be focused on public areas relevant to the CCTV scheme’s purpose, and privacy intrusions must be minimised.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A large political protest is taking place in a town square covered by public space CCTV. How should the operator balance security with people’s rights?

options.A: Automatically track and record every protester’s face for possible future offences
options.B: Turn off all cameras because protests must never be monitored
options.C: Post their own comments about protesters on social media using CCTV images
options.D: Monitor proportionately, focusing on safety and crime, while recognising people’s freedom of expression

explanation: Article 10 protects freedom of expression, which includes peaceful protest. CCTV can still be used to maintain public safety and prevent crime, but monitoring should be proportionate and not used to suppress lawful protest or unlawfully profile individuals.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: How many protected characteristics are covered by the Equality Act 2010?
explanation: The Equality Act 2010 lists nine protected characteristics: age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage and civil partnership, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sex and sexual orientation. CCTV operators must avoid discriminatory behaviour linked to any of these.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which situation is the best example of indirect discrimination in a CCTV context?

options.A: An operator deliberately watches people of one race more closely because they “look suspicious”
options.B: A camera placement plan that leaves disabled access routes uncovered, even though other entrances are fully covered
options.C: Making sexual jokes about a person seen on camera
options.D: Treating a colleague badly for supporting a discrimination complaint

explanation: Indirect discrimination happens when a policy or practice applies to everyone but disadvantages a particular protected group. Failing to cover disabled access routes could disadvantage disabled people compared with others, unless it could be objectively justified.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which of the following is a protected characteristic under the Equality Act 2010?

options.A: Accent
options.B: Job title
options.C: Pregnancy and maternity
options.D: Car ownership

explanation: Pregnancy and maternity is one of the nine protected characteristics. Accent, job title and car ownership are not protected characteristics under the Equality Act, so different treatment based purely on those would not be covered by that Act.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A CCTV operator supports a colleague’s formal complaint that they were racially discriminated against. Afterwards, the supervisor stops offering the operator overtime and makes their job more difficult. What is this behaviour an example of under the Equality Act?

options.A: Direct discrimination
options.B: Indirect discrimination
options.C: Harassment
options.D: Victimisation

explanation: Victimisation is treating someone badly because they have made, or supported, a complaint about discrimination. The operator is being penalised for supporting a discrimination complaint, which fits the definition of victimisation.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Under data protection law, how is CCTV footage that identifies individuals generally classified?

options.A: Personal data
options.B: Structural data
options.C: Technical data, not covered by law
options.D: Unregulated visual information

explanation: Images from CCTV that identify living individuals are personal data. This means they are covered by the Data Protection Act 2018 and UK GDPR, and must be handled lawfully, fairly, securely and only for specified purposes.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A friend phones a CCTV operator and asks to see last night’s footage because a celebrity was visiting the shopping centre. What should the operator do?

options.A: Show the footage, as long as the friend doesn’t record it
options.B: Refuse and explain that sharing images with unauthorised people breaches data protection and confidentiality
options.C: Email a short clip to the friend so they can watch it at home
options.D: Allow viewing only if the celebrity has posted about their visit on social media

explanation: CCTV footage is personal data and must only be disclosed lawfully to authorised persons for legitimate reasons. Friends and members of the public are not authorised just because they are curious, so the operator must refuse and maintain confidentiality.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which action best demonstrates data minimisation in a CCTV system?

options.A: Storing all footage indefinitely, just in case
options.B: Using as many cameras as possible, whether needed or not
options.C: Keeping footage only for the defined retention period needed for its security purpose
options.D: Allowing all staff to access all footage whenever they wish

explanation: Data minimisation means collecting and keeping only the minimum personal data necessary for the stated purpose. Having a clear retention period and deleting footage when it is no longer needed supports this principle.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A person comes to the control room demanding that footage of a serious assault (in which they appear) is deleted immediately, claiming a “right to be forgotten”. The police have already asked for the footage as evidence. What should the operator do?

options.A: Delete the footage immediately to respect the person’s rights
options.B: Refuse and say they have no rights over CCTV images
options.C: Give them a copy and then delete the original to keep everyone happy
options.D: Explain that the footage may need to be kept as evidence and refer them to the organisation’s data controller / subject access procedures

explanation: The right to erasure is limited, especially where data is needed for legal claims or criminal investigations. The operator should not delete potential evidence. They should follow policy, ensure the footage is secured, and direct the person to the correct subject access or complaints process.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Under the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974, what is an employer’s general duty towards employees such as CCTV operators?

options.A: To ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, their health, safety and welfare at work
options.B: To guarantee that no accidents or incidents ever occur
options.C: To provide free meals on every shift
options.D: To ensure employees never work night shifts

explanation: Employers must, so far as is reasonably practicable, provide a safe working environment, safe systems of work, information, instruction and training. They cannot guarantee absolute safety, but they must take sensible, proportionate steps to reduce risks.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: To comply with the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999, what should an employer do about risks from CCTV workstations?

options.A: Rely on staff to complain if anything feels uncomfortable
options.B: Carry out and record a risk assessment of the workstations, implement controls and review them regularly
options.C: Buy larger monitors and assume that removes all risk
options.D: Only look at risks after someone has been injured

explanation: The regulations require employers to assess risks, record significant findings (if they have 5 or more employees), put control measures in place and review them. This includes assessing display screen and workstation risks in a control room.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: For several years, staff have warned management that the CCTV control room’s fire exit is blocked by equipment. No action is taken. A fire breaks out and an operator dies because they cannot escape. Which offence could the organisation potentially be prosecuted for?

options.A: Individual gross negligence manslaughter of the supervisor
options.B: Harassment under the Equality Act 2010
options.C: Corporate manslaughter under the Corporate Manslaughter and Corporate Homicide Act 2007
options.D: Ordinary breach of contract

explanation: Where a gross breach of a duty of care by an organisation’s senior management leads to someone’s death, the organisation may be prosecuted for corporate manslaughter. Failing over time to deal with a serious known safety risk such as a blocked fire exit could amount to such a breach.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A CCTV operator reports eye strain and wrist pain from long periods at the monitors. Under the Display Screen Equipment Regulations, which action is most appropriate?

options.A: Tell them to ignore it because it’s part of the job
options.B: Ask them to work longer shifts so they “get used to it”
options.C: Turn off some monitors but change nothing else
options.D: Review their workstation assessment, ensure adjustable equipment and regular breaks, and offer an eye test if required

explanation: Display Screen Equipment Regulations require employers to assess workstations, provide suitable adjustable equipment, ensure regular breaks from screens and provide eye tests on request. This helps prevent eye strain and musculoskeletal problems.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Under RIDDOR 2013, who is normally responsible for reporting a work-related death or serious injury to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE)?

options.A: The employer or person in control of the work premises
options.B: Any employee who witnessed the incident
options.C: The injured person’s family
options.D: The CCTV operator personally, in all cases

explanation: RIDDOR places the duty to report on employers, self‑employed people and those in control of work premises. Employees, including CCTV operators, must report incidents internally but do not usually make the official RIDDOR report themselves.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A CCTV operator slips in the control room, injures their back and is unable to work for 10 consecutive days. What should happen under RIDDOR?

options.A: No action is required because they were not taken to hospital
options.B: The employer must report the incident to HSE as an over-seven-day injury
options.C: The injured operator must personally telephone HSE
options.D: The accident only needs to be written in the accident book

explanation: RIDDOR requires employers to report work-related injuries that result in an employee being unable to perform their normal work for more than seven consecutive days (not counting the day of the accident). Ten days off means the employer must submit a report.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which of the following actions would be outside the legal powers of a CCTV operator working in a town-centre control room?

options.A: Observing an incident and directing police officers to the location
options.B: Providing a copy of relevant footage to authorised police officers following procedure
options.C: Demanding that a member of the public on camera shows identification and remains where they are until police arrive
options.D: Giving a witness statement to the police describing what was seen on CCTV

explanation: CCTV operators have no special powers. They cannot demand identification or detain people. Their role is to observe, record, and pass information and evidence to those who do have powers, such as the police or on‑site security staff.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A CCTV operator in a warehouse control room sees a large storage rack collapse. No one is hurt, but falling loads narrowly miss two workers and could easily have killed them. How should this incident normally be treated under RIDDOR?

options.A: It does not need to be recorded because no one was injured
options.B: It is just a training issue and not an accident
options.C: It is a matter for the workers to sort out between themselves
options.D: It is a dangerous occurrence and the employer may need to report it to HSE

explanation: RIDDOR covers certain “dangerous occurrences” – serious near misses that could have caused death or serious injury. A major equipment collapse narrowly missing workers is likely to fall into this category and may need to be reported by the employer.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: In a criminal case where CCTV footage is used as evidence, what standard of proof must the prosecution meet?

options.A: Beyond reasonable doubt
options.B: Balance of probabilities
options.C: On the word of the victim alone
options.D: Whatever the judge thinks is fair on the day

explanation: In criminal law the prosecution must prove the defendant’s guilt “beyond reasonable doubt” (the court must be sure). This is a higher standard than in civil cases.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A customer sues a shopping centre for compensation after tripping on a loose tile. CCTV footage is used to show what happened. What type of law is this mainly an example of?

options.A: Criminal law
options.B: Civil law
options.C: Human rights law
options.D: Corporate manslaughter law

explanation: The customer is bringing a claim for compensation for alleged negligence, which is a civil matter. Civil cases are usually decided on the balance of probabilities, not beyond reasonable doubt.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: CCTV footage of a fight is used first in a criminal trial for assault, and later in a civil claim for compensation. Which statement best describes the difference between the criminal and civil cases?

options.A: In both cases the claimant must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt
options.B: In both cases the state must prove the case on the balance of probabilities
options.C: In the criminal case, the injured person must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt; in the civil case, the police must prove their case on the balance of probabilities
options.D: In the criminal case, the prosecution must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt; in the civil case, the claimant must prove their case on the balance of probabilities

explanation: In a criminal case the prosecution (on behalf of the state) must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt. In a civil claim the claimant (injured party) must prove their case on the balance of probabilities. The same CCTV footage can be used in both types of case.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A manager tells the CCTV operator to radio store staff and instruct them to search a suspect’s bag and detain them until police arrive, based solely on what the operator has seen on camera. What is the most appropriate response?

options.A: Immediately instruct staff to search and detain, because CCTV gives the operator that authority
options.B: Phone the suspect directly and tell them to stay where they are
options.C: Pass information about the suspect and incident to appropriate responders without instructing anyone to search or detain, as the operator has no special powers
options.D: Post the suspect’s image on social media to warn other shops

explanation: CCTV operators have no greater powers than ordinary citizens. They can observe, record and pass information to police or authorised security staff, but they should not direct unlawful searches or detentions.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which of the following is a core part of a CCTV operator’s role in public space surveillance?

options.A: Observing incidents, recording what is seen and alerting appropriate responders
options.B: Deciding which suspects should be charged with offences
options.C: Issuing on-the-spot fines to people seen on camera
options.D: Carrying out stop-and-search on people acting suspiciously

explanation: The CCTV operator’s role is to observe and record events, direct responding staff and preserve evidence. Decisions about charging, stop-and-search and enforcement are for the police or other authorised personnel, not the operator.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A control room manager tells an operator: “Spend most of your time watching teenage boys wearing hoodies, especially if they’re black – they cause most of the trouble.” What is the best response?

options.A: Follow the instruction; the manager is responsible, not the operator
options.B: Challenge or report the instruction because it is discriminatory profiling based on age and race, breaching Equality Act principles
options.C: Only follow the instruction if the teenagers also look nervous
options.D: Zoom in on them as requested but delete all recordings later

explanation: Targeting people for extra monitoring purely because of race and age is discriminatory profiling. This conflicts with the Equality Act and the Human Rights Act (Article 14 – non‑discrimination). The operator should not follow such instructions and should raise the issue through appropriate channels. unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Where does a public space CCTV operator normally carry out most of their duties?

options.A: On a foot patrol of the town centre
options.B: In a control room monitoring screens and communications
options.C: On the door of a licensed venue checking ID
options.D: Driving a mobile patrol vehicle

explanation: CCTV operators are remote observers based in a control room, using multiple monitors and communications systems. They are not usually patrolling or working at the front line with the public.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: What is the MAIN way a CCTV operator helps protect the public?

options.A: By patrolling the streets and physically challenging suspicious people
options.B: By carrying out searches of people and bags
options.C: By monitoring cameras and passing timely, accurate information to those who can respond
options.D: By issuing fixed penalty notices to offenders at the scene

explanation: The CCTV operator’s power is information. They protect the public by spotting incidents early on camera and directing police or other responders with accurate information, not by physical intervention or enforcement.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which of the following is a key responsibility of a CCTV operator?

options.A: Accurately recording incidents and actions in the incident log
options.B: Conducting personal searches of members of the public
options.C: Deciding which suspects should be prosecuted
options.D: Authorising entry into private premises

explanation: Accurate documentation is a core part of the CCTV operator role, helping to preserve evidence and demonstrate accountability. Detaining, searching or deciding on prosecutions are not part of their role.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: What is meant by a CCTV operator’s “duty of care”?

options.A: Doing whatever your manager tells you, even if it seems unsafe
options.B: Helping colleagues but not needing to consider the public
options.C: A voluntary guideline to assist emergency services if you have time
options.D: A legal and moral obligation to act with reasonable care towards people who may be affected by what you do or fail to do

explanation: Duty of care means you must act with reasonable care towards the public, colleagues, your employer and yourself. Failing to act when you should, or acting negligently, can breach this duty and may have legal consequences.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: While monitoring the town centre, you see a person suddenly collapse and lie motionless on the pavement. What is the MOST appropriate action to fulfil your duty of care?

options.A: Note the time in the log but wait to see if someone else helps
options.B: Immediately alert ambulance control or your radio contact, giving exact location and description, and continue to monitor the scene
options.C: Rewind the footage to see what happened before the collapse and deal with it later
options.D: Do nothing because you are not medically trained

explanation: Duty of care requires prompt action. The operator should quickly alert the appropriate emergency service and provide accurate information, while continuing to monitor. Simply watching, delaying, or doing nothing fails that duty.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: During a busy afternoon shift you notice an elderly person on camera who appears confused and is wandering close to a busy main road. No crime is taking place and your supervisor earlier said, “Just focus on crime today, we’re short staffed.” What should you do to BEST meet your duty of care?

options.A: Ignore the situation because it is not crime-related
options.B: Zoom out from the camera so you are not distracted
options.C: Continue to monitor the person and promptly alert appropriate responders (such as police, street wardens or control) that a vulnerable person may be at risk
options.D: Call the person directly using a public address system and tell them to go home immediately

explanation: Duty of care includes protecting vulnerable persons and not ignoring obvious risks. The operator should continue to observe and alert suitable responders. Giving direct instructions to the public or ignoring the situation would not be appropriate.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which example BEST shows a CCTV operator meeting professional appearance standards in the control room?

options.A: Wearing clean, appropriate clothing or uniform with SIA licence/ID clearly displayed
options.B: Wearing a football shirt and trainers as long as no member of the public visits the room
options.C: Keeping a coat over the chair so your SIA licence is not visible
options.D: Wearing headphones and a hoodie so you can concentrate on the screens

explanation: Professional standards require a clean, presentable appearance and visible ID/licence. Informal or obscured dress damages the professional image expected of CCTV operators.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: After a serious incident in the town centre, your friend messages you: “You were on the cameras – what actually happened? Send me a clip!” To maintain professional standards, what should you do?

options.A: Send your friend a short clip privately as long as they promise not to share it
options.B: Tell them basic details and say you will show them the footage after your shift
options.C: Post a still image from the incident on your personal social media, but blur the faces
options.D: Explain that you cannot discuss or share CCTV footage and refer them to official police or council information

explanation: Confidentiality is critical. CCTV images must not be shared with unauthorised people or on social media. The professional response is to refuse to share and direct them to official channels.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: You arrive 15 minutes late for your control-room shift, meaning some cameras were not monitored and the outgoing operator could not give a proper handover. Which professional standard have you MOST clearly failed to meet?

options.A: Duty of care to yourself
options.B: Confidentiality
options.C: Punctuality and reliability
options.D: Customer service to the police

explanation: Being on time so there is a proper handover and continuous monitoring is a key standard. While poor punctuality can affect service to others, the clearest standard broken here is punctuality and reliability.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which action is OUTSIDE the normal authority of a CCTV operator?

options.A: Observing and recording incidents on camera
options.B: Physically detaining a suspected shoplifter in the street
options.C: Passing information to police by radio
options.D: Providing recorded footage to authorised investigators

explanation: CCTV operators have no special power to detain people. Their role is to observe, record and report, not to physically intervene. Detention is for the police or others with appropriate authority.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: While monitoring a fight, a police officer on the radio says, “Can you go outside and help hold that suspect until we arrive?” What is the MOST appropriate response for the CCTV operator?

options.A: Explain that you cannot physically intervene, continue monitoring the incident and provide clear, accurate updates to the officer
options.B: Leave the control room immediately to help restrain the suspect, leaving the cameras unattended
options.C: Lock the control-room door and turn off the monitors until the incident is over
options.D: Refuse to help in any way because it is “a police matter”

explanation: The operator must stay within their authority and maintain surveillance. They should not leave the control room to intervene physically, but they should support the police by providing good information.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: A new colleague says, “Now we work in the CCTV control room we have more power than ordinary people – we can detain people and demand ID if we need to.” Which reply shows the BEST understanding of your legal authority?

options.A: “Yes, we can detain anyone seen committing an offence until the police arrive.”
options.B: “We can demand ID, but only if we explain we are CCTV staff.”
options.C: “We can search people if we have clear evidence of theft on camera.”
options.D: “No, we have NO special legal powers – we only have the same powers as any ordinary member of the public and must work through police and other responders.”

explanation: CCTV operators have no special legal powers. They cannot demand ID, search or detain beyond what any ordinary citizen could legally do. Their role is to observe, record and report.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Who is usually the CCTV operator’s PRIMARY partner when responding to crime and disorder in public spaces?

options.A: Local schools
options.B: Private taxi firms
options.C: The police
options.D: Local newspapers

explanation: Police are the main operational partner for CCTV operators, relying on timely, accurate information and evidence from the control room.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: You are tracking a suspected thief on camera. A police unit radios: “Control, can you update us?” What information will be MOST useful for the officers?

options.A: Your opinion on why the suspect is behaving suspiciously
options.B: Clear factual details such as clothing, exact location, direction of travel and anything the suspect is carrying
options.C: The suspect’s possible name based on what other staff think
options.D: A general comment that the suspect is “somewhere in the town centre”

explanation: Police need precise, factual information to locate and safely deal with suspects. Opinions, guesses and vague locations are far less useful.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: From the control room you see smoke and flames coming from a rubbish bin outside a busy shopping centre. No one appears injured. Which partner should you contact FIRST?

options.A: Local authority licensing team
options.B: Retail radio scheme
options.C: Ambulance service
options.D: Fire and rescue service

explanation: A fire is an immediate safety risk. The fire and rescue service should be alerted first so they can respond quickly, while the operator continues to monitor and support other partners as needed.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which of the following is a common safety control for a lone-working CCTV operator on a night shift?

options.A: Turning off external phones so no one can disturb you
options.B: Having regular check-in calls or messages with a supervisor or monitoring point
options.C: Leaving the control-room door propped open to feel less isolated
options.D: Refusing to handle any incidents after midnight

explanation: Lone working procedures usually include regular check-ins and clear communication routes. Propping doors open or refusing incidents increases risk rather than controlling it.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: You are alone in the control room on a night shift. Your relief calls to say they are running one hour late and tells you to “just lock up and go, nothing ever happens at this time.” What is the MOST appropriate action, considering lone working and duty of care?

options.A: Inform your supervisor or control contact and remain on duty until safe cover or instructions are arranged, even if this means working beyond your scheduled finish time
options.B: Lock the control room and leave immediately at your scheduled finish time
options.C: Switch off all cameras but leave the lights on so it looks occupied
options.D: Open the control-room door so police can walk in if there is a problem

explanation: The control room should not be left unattended without proper authorisation. The operator should escalate the issue and maintain cover until safe arrangements are made, balancing duty of care to the public, colleagues and themselves.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Why is it important for CCTV operators to follow agreed Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)?

options.A: So that each operator can do things in their own preferred way
options.B: To avoid having to make any decisions during a shift
options.C: To ensure work is carried out consistently, safely and in line with legal and organisational requirements
options.D: To reduce the amount of information that has to be recorded

explanation: SOPs support consistent practice, legal compliance, safety and quality. They help show that the system is operated professionally and can be audited if something goes wrong.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: You face an unusual situation on camera that is not covered by any current procedure. What is the BEST way to deal with it?

options.A: Ignore it, because if it is not in the procedures it is not your responsibility
options.B: Make up your own method but do not tell anyone in case it is criticised
options.C: Wait until the next team meeting before taking any action
options.D: Use your professional judgement to deal with the situation safely, seek guidance from a supervisor where possible, and fully document what you did so procedures can be reviewed

explanation: Procedures cannot cover every situation. Operators should act safely and sensibly, seek guidance, and document their decisions so the organisation can learn and update SOPs if needed.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which organisation licenses CCTV operators working in public space surveillance within the private security industry?

options.A: The Security Industry Authority (SIA)
options.B: The Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO)
options.C: The Fire and Rescue Service
options.D: The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS)

explanation: The SIA is the regulator for the private security industry and issues licences for roles such as CCTV operators. The ICO deals with data protection, not licensing.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: Which action BEST demonstrates accountability in the CCTV control room?

options.A: Deleting footage quickly to free up space for new recordings
options.B: Relying on memory instead of completing written incident logs
options.C: Keeping accurate, timely records of incidents and actions taken, creating an audit trail that can be checked
options.D: Only telling supervisors about incidents that make you look good

explanation: Accountability is shown through accurate records, audit trails and transparent operations. Logs demonstrate what was done, when and why, and can be reviewed by employers, regulators or courts.

unitTitle: Working in the Private Security Industry
question: While monitoring a quiet period, you become distracted by a personal text message and miss the start of a serious assault that was visible on one of the cameras. You realise your mistake when police later ask for footage. What is the MOST appropriate way to respond?

options.A: Edit the log to pretend you were watching the camera the whole time, so you will not get into trouble
options.B: Be honest about what happened, report the lapse to your supervisor, ensure all available footage is preserved and cooperate with any review to prevent it happening again
options.C: Delete the footage so no one can see that you missed the incident
options.D: Blame a technical fault on the system, even though you know it was working normally

explanation: Accountability means accepting responsibility when things go wrong. The operator must preserve evidence, be honest, report promptly and learn from the mistake. Falsifying records or destroying evidence is unethical and could be illegal.
