question: A serious explosion occurs near a crowded transport hub. On CCTV you can see numerous casualties, heavy smoke and traffic gridlock. Multiple agencies start calling the control room for updates. What should be your main priority as the CCTV operator?

options.A: Turn off all recordings to prevent the footage from being used in any future investigation
options.B: Stop monitoring the incident and concentrate on answering questions from the media
options.C: Immediately rewind all cameras to see exactly how the incident began, ignoring live pictures until you have done so
options.D: Make sure the emergency services have been alerted, then focus on providing them with clear real‑time information and marking footage for preservation

explanation: In a major incident, the CCTV operator’s priorities are to ensure the alarm is raised, support the emergency services with accurate real‑time information, and preserve footage for investigation. Media enquiries and other issues are secondary to life‑saving coordination.

question: What is a PRIMARY purpose of public space CCTV systems?

options.A: To replace the need for police patrols entirely
options.B: To increase advertising opportunities for businesses
options.C: To monitor staff punctuality in nearby offices
options.D: To help prevent and detect crime in public areas

explanation: Public space CCTV is mainly used to help prevent crime (through deterrence) and detect crime (by observing and recording incidents). It supports, rather than replaces, police patrols and is not installed for advertising or staff‑monitoring purposes.

question: Which statement best describes public reassurance as a purpose of public space CCTV?

options.A: Ensuring all incidents are broadcast on local news
options.B: Helping people feel safer because they know public spaces are monitored
options.C: Allowing members of the public to watch CCTV monitors
options.D: Guaranteeing no crime will occur anywhere in the town

explanation: Public reassurance means that people feel safer and more confident using public spaces because they know CCTV is being used to monitor and respond to incidents. CCTV cannot guarantee that crime will never occur.

question: A shopkeeper complains that CCTV has “failed” because a theft still happened in front of a camera. Which response BEST explains a limitation of CCTV?

options.A: CCTV can deter and help detect crime, but it cannot prevent all offending or cover every area
options.B: CCTV prevents serious crime but not minor offences such as theft
options.C: CCTV always stops crime, so the cameras must have been switched off
options.D: CCTV only works indoors, so outdoor cameras never deter crime

explanation: CCTV is a valuable tool, but it has limitations. It can deter some offenders and provide evidence after an incident, yet it cannot stop all crime or see every angle. Crime can still occur even in monitored areas.

question: Which of the following is a CORE function of a CCTV operator in a public space control room?

options.A: Patrolling the streets and physically breaking up fights
options.B: Actively monitoring camera images to identify incidents and risk
options.C: Issuing fixed penalty notices to offenders
options.D: Repairing faulty cameras and cabling

explanation: The operator’s core role is to monitor cameras, detect incidents and communicate with partners. They do not patrol the streets, repair equipment, or issue penalties; those tasks belong to other roles.

question: During a live incident, patrol officers are on their way to a reported fight in the town centre. What is the CCTV operator’s MOST important contribution while watching the cameras?

options.A: Zoom in as close as possible on one person, even if they lose the wider view
options.B: Wait until officers arrive, then write a report afterwards
options.C: Provide clear, real-time updates on suspects’ location, appearance and any weapons seen
options.D: Turn off nearby cameras to protect the privacy of bystanders

explanation: In a live incident, the operator’s key function is to support responders. Providing accurate, real‑time information about suspects, risks and movements helps officers reach the right place quickly and safely.

question: An arrest has been made following an assault seen on CCTV. What is the MOST appropriate action for the operator regarding the footage?

options.A: Post a still image from the footage on social media to help identify witnesses
options.B: Secure the relevant footage and follow procedures to preserve evidence and maintain chain of custody
options.C: Delete all footage of the incident once the suspect has been taken into custody
options.D: Make a personal copy of the footage to watch later in case it is needed

explanation: Evidence management is a key function. The operator must ensure relevant footage is identified, secured and handled according to procedure so that its integrity is maintained for any criminal or civil proceedings.

question: Which of the following would you EXPECT to find in a properly designed CCTV control room?

options.A: Rows of open windows with the public looking in
options.B: Multiple monitors, CCTV control equipment and secure access
options.C: A shop till and public-facing counter
options.D: A loud public address system constantly playing music

explanation: A control room is a secure environment with multiple monitors, control equipment and communication systems. Public access and distractions (like loud music) would undermine security and concentration.

question: A CCTV operator reports regular neck and eye strain during their shift. Which action would MOST help address the control room working environment?

options.A: Turning all the monitors to maximum brightness
options.B: Turning off half the monitors to reduce the amount of work
options.C: Adjusting screen height and position, chair settings and lighting to reduce glare and improve posture
options.D: Opening blinds fully so direct sunlight shines on the screens

explanation: Good ergonomics – correctly positioned screens, suitable seating and controlled lighting – help reduce strain and fatigue. Bright glare, poorly placed screens or simply turning equipment off do not address the underlying issue.

question: Which skill is MOST closely linked to spotting small but important changes in behaviour or surroundings on camera?

options.A: Ability to drive emergency vehicles
options.B: Knowledge of building maintenance
options.C: Fast typing speed
options.D: Strong observation skills

explanation: Observation is an essential skill for CCTV operators. Being able to notice small details and changes in behaviour helps with early detection of incidents and risks.

question: Which personal quality BEST helps a CCTV operator avoid misusing camera systems for personal reasons?

options.A: Curiosity
options.B: Confidence
options.C: Sense of humour
options.D: Integrity

explanation: Integrity means acting honestly and ethically, even when no one is watching. Operators with integrity follow procedures, respect privacy and do not use CCTV for personal or improper purposes.

question: During a live search for a missing teenager, the police ask the CCTV operator for a description of a person seen on camera. What is the MOST appropriate way to respond?

options.A: Give a vague description such as “young person in casual clothes” to keep it brief
options.B: Wait until the teenager has left camera view and then send a written report
options.C: Use technical camera terms that demonstrate expertise with the system
options.D: Provide a clear, structured description including clothing, distinguishing features, exact location and direction of travel

explanation: Effective communication means giving accurate, structured and useful information. Clear descriptions of appearance, location and movement help officers quickly identify the person they are looking for.

question: In most public space CCTV schemes, which organisation is the PRIMARY operational partner when responding to crime in progress?

options.A: Environmental health team
options.B: Police
options.C: Ambulance service
options.D: Local business association

explanation: While CCTV control rooms work with many partners, the police are usually the main operational partner for crime in progress, as they have the powers to investigate, detain and arrest.

question: Repeated late-night anti-social behaviour and licensing breaches are occurring outside a group of bars in the town centre. With which partner should the CCTV control room MOST likely work to tackle these issues strategically?

options.A: The local bus company
options.B: A national news channel
options.C: The coastguard
options.D: The local authority’s community safety / licensing team

explanation: Local authorities – particularly community safety and licensing teams – are key partners for dealing with anti-social behaviour linked to licensed premises. They can coordinate enforcement and long-term solutions.

question: On a busy Saturday evening, the CCTV operator sees a person collapse in a crowded pedestrian area. People gather around and the nearest road access is partly blocked by parked vehicles. What is the MOST appropriate immediate course of action?

options.A: Call the ambulance service, then guide them and the police to the scene using cameras, monitoring the crowd and access routes for hazards
options.B: Announce on social media that there is an emergency and ask the public to move vehicles
options.C: Use the cameras to zoom in closely on the casualty’s face and do nothing else until the picture is perfect
options.D: Wait to see if members of the public deal with the situation before contacting any partner agencies

explanation: Supporting emergency services is a key purpose of CCTV. The operator should promptly alert the ambulance service (and police if required), then use cameras to direct them efficiently and monitor access and crowd safety.

question: Which of the following is an example of reactive monitoring?

options.A: Planning which cameras to use for an upcoming football match
options.B: Watching school routes at home time to deter bullying
options.C: Focusing cameras on a street only after the police report a fight there
options.D: Routinely scanning known trouble spots before the pubs close

explanation: Reactive monitoring means responding to something that has already been reported, such as a police call or alarm activation. Proactive monitoring involves searching for problems before they are reported.

question: After dealing with several earlier incidents, the control room is quiet and no requests are coming in. What is the BEST example of proactive monitoring that still allows the operator to respond quickly to new incidents?

options.A: Rewinding recordings from earlier in the day for personal interest
options.B: Using the time to check personal emails on the control room computer
options.C: Turning all cameras towards quiet residential streets and leaving them there
options.D: Conducting a systematic camera patrol of known hotspots and vulnerable locations while listening out for any new calls

explanation: Proactive monitoring means actively looking for issues, especially in known hotspots or vulnerable locations. The operator should continue to scan live images and remain ready to react to any new information.

question: A lone CCTV operator is proactively monitoring a known trouble spot near a pub late on Friday night. A Shopwatch radio call reports a suspected shoplifter who has quietly left a nearby store. At the same time, the operator sees a large, noisy crowd forming outside the pub where serious assaults have happened before. What is the MOST appropriate action?

options.A: Prioritise monitoring the developing crowd near the pub, alerting police if needed, while briefly checking the shoplifter area when possible and recording details from the Shopwatch report
options.B: Ignore the crowd near the pub and focus only on the suspected shoplifter because the request came in by radio
options.C: Split the main monitor between replaying last night’s incidents and live cameras to show they are being proactive
options.D: Stop all monitoring and immediately start reviewing earlier footage in case something was missed

explanation: Operators must balance reactive requests with proactive risk assessment. A large, potentially volatile crowd at a known trouble spot presents a higher immediate risk than a non‑violent suspected shoplifter who has already left. Monitoring the crowd and informing police while recording shoplifter details is a risk‑based, proportionate response.

question: Which of the following actions is WITHIN the normal scope of a CCTV operator’s role?

options.A: Forcing entry into private premises to check what is happening
options.B: Directing police officers by radio to a suspect while monitoring them on camera
options.C: Issuing on‑the‑spot fines to offenders seen on CCTV
options.D: Stopping and searching a suspect in the street

explanation: CCTV operators do not have extra powers to stop, search or fine people. They support those who do, such as the police, by monitoring cameras and providing accurate information and guidance.

question: While monitoring cameras, a CCTV operator sees two groups arguing aggressively, and one person is holding a bottle in a threatening way. No call has yet been received. What is the MOST appropriate action?

options.A: Treat it as a potential serious incident, inform the police or appropriate partner immediately, and continue monitoring to provide updates
options.B: Leave the control room to try to calm the situation in person
options.C: Do nothing until someone calls the control room or police
options.D: Send the footage to friends to see what they think before deciding

explanation: The operator’s role is to observe and report, not physically intervene. This could escalate into violence, so it should be reported promptly to police or the appropriate partner, with ongoing updates from the cameras.

question: During an incident, the operator sees a person holding a small dark object. The police radio in and ask, “Can you confirm it’s a knife?” The image is unclear. What should the operator do?

options.A: Say it is not a knife because there is no absolute proof
options.B: Confirm that it is definitely a knife so that officers treat it as high risk
options.C: Explain honestly that the object cannot be clearly identified, describe exactly what can be seen, and let officers assess the risk
options.D: Refuse to answer the question and switch cameras to avoid involvement

explanation: Operators must stay within their limitations and be honest about what they can and cannot see. They should accurately describe the image without guessing, allowing officers to assess risk based on the best available information.

question: You notice a colleague using their mobile phone to photograph images on the CCTV monitor of a celebrity in the town centre “for personal use”. What is the MOST appropriate response?

options.A: Ignore it, as no crime has taken place
options.B: Challenge or report the behaviour in line with procedures, as this is an inappropriate use of CCTV images
options.C: Post the image on your own social media to warn others the celebrity is in town
options.D: Ask them to send you a copy so you can both keep it

explanation: Professionalism and confidentiality are vital. Capturing CCTV images on a personal device is misuse of the system and a potential data protection breach. It should be challenged and reported according to local policy.

question: During a night shift, a close friend phones the control room and asks you to use the cameras to see whether their ex‑partner is in town and who they are with, saying, “It’s only for me, nobody else will know.” What is the MOST appropriate response?

options.A: Check briefly and give only a yes/no answer
options.B: Ask another operator to do it so you are not personally involved
options.C: Refuse the request, explain that this would be misuse of the system, and follow local procedures for reporting inappropriate requests if necessary
options.D: Agree, as long as you do not save any still images

explanation: Using CCTV for personal reasons is unethical and may be illegal. Operators must refuse such requests, explain their professional obligations and, where required, record or report the attempt to misuse the system.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Under the Protection of Freedoms Act 2012, which body oversees the Surveillance Camera Code of Practice?

options.A: The Information Commissioner's Office
options.B: The Security Industry Authority
options.C: The Biometrics and Surveillance Camera Commissioner
options.D: The Home Office

explanation: The Biometrics and Surveillance Camera Commissioner oversees the Surveillance Camera Code of Practice. This role replaced the former Surveillance Camera Commissioner in 2022. They promote compliance with the Code, provide guidance, review how it is implemented and report to Parliament.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A town-centre public space CCTV scheme is operated by the local council. Why must the council have regard to the Surveillance Camera Code of Practice?

options.A: Because as a “relevant authority” under the Protection of Freedoms Act 2012, it is legally required to have regard to the Code when using CCTV
options.B: Because every SIA CCTV licence holder is personally criminally liable if the Code is not followed
options.C: Because the Code is criminal law that applies to anyone who owns a camera, including private householders
options.D: Because otherwise the local media automatically gain control over the CCTV system

explanation: Police, Police and Crime Commissioners, local authorities and certain other public bodies are “relevant authorities” under the Protection of Freedoms Act 2012 and must have regard to the Surveillance Camera Code of Practice when operating surveillance camera systems. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A privately run shopping centre has its own CCTV control room. How does the Surveillance Camera Code of Practice generally apply to them?

options.A: It has no relevance at all to private sector CCTV systems
options.B: It only applies to cameras that face onto public roads
options.C: It applies in exactly the same mandatory way as it does to the police and local authorities
options.D: It is voluntary, but widely regarded as best practice and may be required by contracts or policies

explanation: For most private sector operators, the Code is not legally mandatory but is strongly recommended as best practice. Many contracts with public bodies, insurers or clients expect compliance with the Code and its 12 guiding principles. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Which of the following best describes Guiding Principle 1 of the Surveillance Camera Code of Practice?

options.A: CCTV use must be as transparent as possible, with published contact points for information and complaints
options.B: CCTV must only be used for a specified purpose which is in pursuit of a legitimate aim and necessary to meet an identified pressing need
options.C: Access to retained images must be restricted with clear rules on who can view them and for what reasons
options.D: Any reference database used for matching must be accurate and kept up to date

explanation: Guiding Principle 1 requires that a surveillance camera system is used only for a clearly specified purpose, in pursuit of a legitimate aim, and where its use is necessary to meet an identified pressing need. This goes to the heart of justifying why CCTV is installed at all. Stockton-on-Tees Borough Council

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Guiding Principle 2 mainly requires CCTV operators to:

options.A: Consider the impact of surveillance on individuals and their privacy and carry out regular reviews to ensure the system remains justified
options.B: Store all captured images indefinitely in case they are needed in the future
options.C: Publish all CCTV footage online so the public can review it
options.D: Allow any member of staff to view recordings to “improve awareness”

explanation: Principle 2 focuses on privacy and proportionality. Operators must take into account the effect on individuals and regularly review the system to ensure its continued justification, adjusting it if it becomes disproportionate.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Which data protection principle requires CCTV operators to ensure that time stamps and information on recordings are correct and kept up to date?

options.A: Lawfulness, fairness and transparency
options.B: Accuracy
options.C: Storage limitation
options.D: Accountability

explanation: The accuracy principle under UK GDPR and the Data Protection Act 2018 requires personal data to be accurate and, where necessary, kept up to date. This includes ensuring that time and date settings and camera identifiers are correct so the footage can be reliably used as evidence. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: During a review meeting, your control room manager suggests increasing retention of all public space CCTV recordings from 31 days to 12 months, even though there is no evidence this is needed. They also propose adding cameras inside staff rest areas “just in case”. Which principle best supports your concern that this may be excessive?

options.A: Lawfulness, fairness and transparency
options.B: Accountability
options.C: Accuracy
options.D: Data minimisation and storage limitation

explanation: Both the Surveillance Camera Code (Principle 6) and UK GDPR require data minimisation and storage limitation. Only images necessary for the stated purpose should be collected and kept, and they should be deleted once that purpose has been fulfilled. Excessive retention and unnecessary coverage of private staff areas could be disproportionate.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Your company has installed new CCTV in a multi-storey car park. You are asked to check if the proposed signage meets transparency requirements. Which sign wording best satisfies legal expectations?

options.A: “Smile – you’re on camera!”
options.B: “CCTV IN USE”
options.C: “CCTV in operation – operated by ABC Parking Ltd for crime prevention and public safety. Enquiries: 01234 567890”
options.D: “Recording in progress – no liability accepted”

explanation: CCTV signage must clearly state that CCTV is in use, identify the data controller (the organisation operating the system), give the purpose (for example, crime prevention) and provide contact details for enquiries. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A member of the public emails the council CCTV control room requesting a copy of footage showing themselves and states that this is a Subject Access Request (SAR). The request is straightforward. How long does the data controller normally have to respond?

options.A: One calendar month from receipt of the request
options.B: 14 working days from receipt of the request
options.C: 28 calendar days from the end of the month in which the request was made
options.D: 40 working days from receipt of the request

explanation: Under UK GDPR and the Data Protection Act 2018, a controller must usually respond to a SAR without undue delay and within one calendar month of receipt. In complex cases the deadline can be extended by up to a further two months, but the requester must be informed within the first month. WCCTV ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Your organisation receives a very complex SAR for CCTV footage covering multiple cameras and dates. It will take a lot of time to locate and review all relevant images and redact third parties. What may the data controller do about the time limit?

options.A: Automatically extend the time limit by 28 days for every SAR
options.B: Extend the time limit by up to two further months because the request is complex, but inform the requester within the first month
options.C: Extend the time limit indefinitely until staff have time to deal with it
options.D: Refuse the request and tell the person to use the Freedom of Information Act instead

explanation: For complex or numerous SARs, the controller may extend the response period by up to two additional months (maximum three calendar months in total), but must notify the requester of the extension and the reasons within the first month. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A person asks the local authority CCTV control room for “all CCTV footage you hold of me from last Saturday evening”, saying they will make a Freedom of Information request. What is the most appropriate advice?

options.A: Treat it as a Freedom of Information Act request because CCTV recordings are always FOI matters
options.B: Tell them they must ask the police because CCTV footage cannot be supplied directly to the public
options.C: Explain that because they are asking for their own personal data, they should make a Subject Access Request under data protection law
options.D: Refuse the request because CCTV is exempt from any form of public access

explanation: Requests for a person’s own footage are made under data protection law using a Subject Access Request. FOI is used to request general recorded information held by public authorities, such as policies, statistics or numbers of cameras, not someone’s personal data (which is normally exempt under FOI). ICO House of Commons Library

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Which of the following CCTV recordings would clearly be treated as personal data under the Data Protection Act 2018 / UK GDPR?

options.A: A heavily blurred image of a crowd where no person can be identified
options.B: An empty corridor with no people or vehicles visible
options.C: A test recording of a camera’s colour bars carried out by an engineer
options.D: A recording clearly showing an identifiable person entering a building along with their vehicle registration number

explanation: Personal data is information relating to an identified or identifiable individual. A clear recording showing a person and their vehicle registration is personal data because the individual can be identified from the images and associated information. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A local authority owns a public space CCTV system but contracts a private company to staff and operate the control room on its behalf. In most cases, who is the data controller for the CCTV footage?

options.A: The local authority
options.B: The private security company operating the control room
options.C: The individual CCTV operator on duty at the time
options.D: The Surveillance Camera Commissioner

explanation: The data controller is the organisation that decides the purposes and means of processing – here, the local authority that owns and determines how the CCTV system is used. The contractor typically acts as a data processor, following the controller’s instructions under a written contract.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: CCTV was installed in a depot car park to prevent theft and vandalism. A manager now wants to use old footage to check which staff arrive late, without informing them and without updating any policies. Which data protection principle is most at risk?

options.A: Accuracy
options.B: Purpose limitation – data must only be used for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes
options.C: Storage limitation
options.D: The right to erasure

explanation: The purpose limitation principle requires that data is collected for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes and not further processed in a way incompatible with those purposes. Using footage collected for crime prevention to secretly monitor staff punctuality is likely to breach this principle. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Which statement about the placement of CCTV warning signs is correct?

options.A: Signs only need to be used if audio is also recorded
options.B: Signs only need to be displayed inside the control room
options.C: Signs should be clearly visible and placed so people can see them before entering the monitored area
options.D: Signs are optional if cameras are mounted on public streets

explanation: To ensure fair and transparent processing, CCTV signs should be clearly visible, legible and positioned so individuals are aware they are entering an area covered by surveillance before they are recorded, typically at points of entry. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A resident complains that a public space CCTV camera overlooks their flat and can see directly into their living room. The camera is also used to monitor a busy pedestrian area where there have been assaults. As a CCTV operator, what is the most appropriate action to suggest?

options.A: Ignore the complaint because there is no expectation of privacy anywhere near a town centre
options.B: Turn the camera off permanently so there is no risk to privacy
options.C: Increase zoom so that the resident’s complaint can be investigated more closely
options.D: Ask that the system owner reviews the camera’s view and uses privacy masking or repositioning so it still meets its security purpose while minimising intrusion into private homes

explanation: Under Article 8 (right to private life) and Guiding Principles 1 and 2, surveillance must be necessary and proportionate. Adjusting the camera or adding privacy masking allows the system to meet its legitimate aim (public safety) while reducing unnecessary intrusion into private homes. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: The police ask you to help set up a hidden camera overlooking a suspect’s front door as part of a specific investigation. They say it will be run as “directed surveillance”. Before assisting, what should you be satisfied about?

options.A: That appropriate RIPA authorisation for directed surveillance has been granted by a designated person and that instructions are documented
options.B: That your shift supervisor thinks it is a good idea
options.C: That the suspect does not live in your local area
options.D: That the camera is hidden well enough that nobody will ever notice it

explanation: Covert, targeted surveillance for a specific investigation that is likely to obtain private information is “directed surveillance” and normally requires authorisation under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 (RIPA) by a designated senior officer. Operators should not carry out such surveillance without proper authorisation and instructions. democracy.towerhamlets.gov.uk

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Which of the following situations would normally not require authorisation under RIPA?

options.A: Covertly placing a hidden camera in a private staff room to monitor an employee
options.B: Routine monitoring of visible town-centre cameras, with CCTV signs displayed to the public
options.C: Plain-clothes officers secretly filming a suspect from an unmarked vehicle
options.D: Installing a hidden camera inside a private home without the occupant’s knowledge

explanation: RIPA is mainly concerned with covert surveillance. Normal overt public space CCTV, where cameras and signage are visible and no specific individual is being covertly targeted, is not usually considered directed surveillance and does not require RIPA authorisation.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A police officer phones the control room and asks for a copy of footage of an assault “as soon as possible”. You do not yet have a written request. What is the most appropriate response?

options.A: Refuse to deal with the police unless they first obtain a court order
options.B: Immediately send the clip to the officer’s personal mobile phone to save time
options.C: Verify the officer’s identity and details of the incident, ask for an auditable request (e.g. form or email), then disclose the necessary footage via the agreed procedure and log the disclosure
options.D: Allow the officer unrestricted access to the control room to view all recordings and take whatever copies they want

explanation: Police are a common lawful recipient of CCTV footage, but operators must still verify identity, ensure there is a lawful basis for disclosure, follow the agreed disclosure procedure (often requiring a written or logged request), and record what was released to maintain an audit trail and chain of custody.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Your system automatically overwrites recordings after 31 days. A member of the public makes a valid SAR for footage of themselves from an incident that happened about six weeks ago. When you check, the footage has already been overwritten. What should the data controller do?

options.A: Try to “undelete” the footage, even if this means hiring a specialist company
options.B: Refuse to reply, as there is no footage so the request is invalid
options.C: Immediately change the retention period to one year and tell the requester you will respond when enough new data has been collected
options.D: Respond within the SAR time limit explaining that the footage is no longer held because it was deleted in line with the documented retention policy, so a copy cannot be provided

explanation: Controllers are not required to keep footage indefinitely “just in case” of SARs. If a SAR is received after footage has been lawfully deleted in accordance with a documented retention schedule, the controller should still respond within the time limit, explaining that the data is no longer held and why.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: You are exporting CCTV of a serious assault for use in court. Which practice best helps to protect the suspect’s right to a fair trial (Article 6) and the evidential value of the footage?

options.A: Following a documented procedure: export the footage, label and seal it, log who handled it and keep the original recording secure and unaltered
options.B: Editing the footage to remove “boring” sections so it is quicker for the court to watch
options.C: Allowing multiple staff to copy the footage onto USB sticks without recording who did so
options.D: Changing the time and date overlay so it matches a witness’s statement

explanation: A clear chain of custody, accurate time and date information and protection of the original recording from alteration all support the reliability and evidential value of CCTV, helping to protect the fairness of any trial.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: After a high-profile incident in the town centre, a TV journalist arrives at the control room and asks you for a copy of the CCTV footage “for broadcast in the public interest”. What should you do?

options.A: Give them a copy immediately because the public have a right to know what happened
options.B: Explain that you cannot release footage directly to the media and refer the request to the data controller’s senior management or press office to consider any lawful basis
options.C: Allow the journalist to sit in the control room and film the CCTV monitors with their own camera
options.D: Tell them to submit a SAR for the footage

explanation: Disclosure to the media is highly sensitive and can seriously affect individuals’ privacy and rights. Such decisions must be taken at an appropriate senior level, weighing up data protection, human rights and any legitimate public interest. Operators should not release footage directly to journalists on their own authority. ICO ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: During routine monitoring, an operator repeatedly uses a PTZ camera to zoom in and follow the same individual walking through the town centre for several minutes, with no operational reason, while ignoring the rest of the scene. What is the main legal/ethical concern?

options.A: It breaches the Freedom of Information Act 2000
options.B: It automatically makes all footage inadmissible in court
options.C: It risks a disproportionate interference with the person’s Article 8 right to private life and could amount to unfair, discriminatory targeting
options.D: It always requires RIPA authorisation because all CCTV use is covert

explanation: Even in public spaces, individuals retain some right to privacy. Targeting one person without justification can be disproportionate and may be seen as unfair profiling or discrimination, conflicting with Article 8 and the principles of fair, proportionate surveillance. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Someone emails the council asking: “How many public space CCTV cameras do you operate and what was the total cost of running them last year?” What is the most appropriate way to treat this request?

options.A: Treat it as a SAR because CCTV is involved
options.B: Refuse the request because CCTV information is confidential
options.C: Tell them to contact the police instead
options.D: Treat it as a Freedom of Information request for general recorded information about the CCTV system

explanation: The Freedom of Information Act 2000 gives anyone the right to request recorded information from public authorities, such as numbers of cameras, policies and costs. This is separate from data protection rights, which relate to personal data about an individual. ICO House of Commons Library

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A colleague asks you to replay footage of a neighbour “just out of curiosity” because they think they saw them in the town centre. There is no operational reason to do this. Which guiding principle best supports your refusal?

options.A: Guiding Principle 7 – access to retained images must be restricted with clear rules on who can access them and for what purpose
options.B: Guiding Principle 3 – transparency and publication of contact points
options.C: Guiding Principle 11 – systems should be used to obtain evidential material when there is a pressing need
options.D: Guiding Principle 8 – technical standards for CCTV equipment

explanation: Principle 7 states that access to retained images must be restricted, with clear rules on who may view them and for what purpose. Viewing footage for curiosity or gossip is an unauthorised purpose and should be refused and reported. Broxtowe

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Which action best demonstrates compliance with Guiding Principle 10 of the Surveillance Camera Code of Practice (review and audit)?

options.A: Deleting all recordings every 7 days without keeping any logs
options.B: Carrying out regular documented audits of the CCTV system, checking compliance with policies and legal requirements, and producing management reports
options.C: Allowing operators to rely only on “common sense” with no written procedures
options.D: Letting engineers make changes to the system without recording what has been done

explanation: Principle 10 requires effective review and audit mechanisms to ensure that legal requirements, policies and standards are complied with in practice, with regular reporting. Documented audits and management reports show that the system is actively monitored for compliance.

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A CCTV operator exports a still image of a well-known local celebrity from the system and shares it on a private social media group as a joke, without any authorisation. What is the most likely consequence for the operator?

options.A: Nothing – there is no issue if it was done outside working hours
options.B: Only the employer can be liable; individual staff cannot face any consequences
options.C: They may face disciplinary action (including possible dismissal) and could potentially be prosecuted for unlawfully obtaining or disclosing personal data
options.D: The system will simply receive a small fixed penalty notice, with no impact on individuals

explanation: Unauthorised disclosure of CCTV images for personal reasons can breach data protection law and internal policies. Individuals can face disciplinary action and, in serious cases, criminal prosecution for unlawfully obtaining or disclosing personal data under the Data Protection Act 2018. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: Which UK body is primarily responsible for enforcing the Data Protection Act 2018 and UK GDPR in relation to CCTV use?

options.A: The Security Industry Authority (SIA)
options.B: The local authority’s licensing department
options.C: The Surveillance Camera Commissioner
options.D: The Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO)

explanation: The Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) is the UK’s independent regulator for data protection and freedom of information. It issues guidance, investigates complaints and can take enforcement action, including fines, where CCTV use breaches data protection law. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: In your control room, exported CCTV discs are kept in an unlocked drawer that many staff can access. One disc containing sensitive incident footage goes missing. Which data protection principle has most clearly been breached, and what might the consequence be?

options.A: Security (integrity and confidentiality) – the ICO could investigate and may issue enforcement or a fine against the controller
options.B: Accuracy – because the footage may now be out of date
options.C: Purpose limitation – because the footage was not reused for another purpose
options.D: Storage limitation – because the footage was not deleted quickly enough

explanation: Controllers must implement appropriate technical and organisational security measures to prevent unauthorised access, loss or theft of personal data. Poor physical security around exported discs breaches the integrity and confidentiality principle and could lead to ICO enforcement action or penalties if harm results. ICO

chapterTitle: LEGISLATION AND CODES OF PRACTICE FOR CCTV
question: A shop owner asks the council CCTV manager to point a public space camera directly at a rival’s entrance “so we can see how busy they are”. There is no evidence of crime or disorder at that location. What is the best reason to refuse this request?

options.A: The camera does not have enough zoom capability
options.B: The request does not meet a legitimate aim or pressing need, so using CCTV in this way would not be necessary or proportionate under Guiding Principle 1 and data protection law
options.C: RIPA requires all CCTV to be authorised for directed surveillance
options.D: SIA licence conditions prevent operators from ever filming shops

explanation: CCTV use must pursue a legitimate aim (such as crime prevention or public safety) and be necessary and proportionate to meet a pressing need. Pointing a public camera at a rival’s entrance purely for commercial curiosity fails these tests and would not comply with Guiding Principle 1 or with data protection and human rights requirements. question: What does PTZ stand for in relation to CCTV cameras?

options.A: Precision Targeting Zone
options.B: Pan-Tilt-Zoom
options.C: Programmable Tracking Zoom
options.D: Power Transmission Zone

explanation: PTZ stands for Pan‑Tilt‑Zoom. Pan is left/right movement, tilt is up/down movement, and zoom is the ability to magnify the image. PTZ cameras allow operators to move the view and zoom in on detail, making them very flexible for town centre and open‑space monitoring.

question: Which type of CCTV camera has a static position with a fixed field of view and cannot be moved remotely?

options.A: PTZ camera
options.B: Dome camera
options.C: Fixed camera
options.D: Thermal camera

explanation: A fixed camera is set to look in one direction with a fixed field of view. It cannot be panned, tilted or zoomed remotely. This makes it ideal for entrances, exits and other specific locations that always need the same area covered.

question: Which camera type is enclosed in a housing that hides the direction it is pointing and often provides vandal resistance?

options.A: Thermal camera
options.B: Fixed box camera
options.C: Day/night camera
options.D: Dome camera

explanation: Dome cameras are contained within a dome housing. This makes it difficult for people to see exactly where the camera is pointing and offers protection against vandalism and weather. Domes can contain either fixed or PTZ mechanisms inside.

question: What do thermal/infrared CCTV cameras primarily detect to create an image?

options.A: Heat signatures from objects and people
options.B: Reflected visible light
options.C: Radio signals from vehicles
options.D: GPS signals from mobile phones

explanation: Thermal/infrared cameras detect heat differences and display heat signatures rather than visible colours. They work in total darkness and are useful for perimeter and night‑time surveillance, but they do not show colour or fine facial detail.

question: On an older analogue town‑centre CCTV system, which device records the analogue camera signals to internal hard drives after converting them to digital?

options.A: Cloud storage server
options.B: Network Video Recorder (NVR)
options.C: Analogue time‑lapse recorder
options.D: Digital Video Recorder (DVR)

explanation: A DVR (Digital Video Recorder) receives analogue video signals, converts them to digital and records them to internal hard drives. It is typically used with analogue cameras and is less scalable and lower resolution than modern NVR‑based IP systems.

question: In the UK, which frame rate is generally used to give smooth CCTV video playback?

options.A: 25 frames per second (fps)
options.B: 5 frames per second (fps)
options.C: 10 frames per second (fps)
options.D: 60 frames per second (fps)

explanation: Around 25 fps is commonly used as the standard for smooth video in the UK. Lower frame rates can look jerky, while higher frame rates use significantly more storage and are usually unnecessary for typical public space surveillance.

question: Which of the following resolutions is commonly referred to as HD (high definition) in CCTV?
explanation: 1280 × 720 is HD (720p) resolution. D1 is standard definition and CIF is a much lower, older format. 3840 × 2160 is 4K, which is ultra‑high definition, not just standard HD.

question: A new IP camera is installed using a single cable that carries both data and power (PoE). Which cable type is MOST likely being used?

options.A: Coaxial cable
options.B: CAT5/CAT6 Ethernet cable
options.C: Fibre optic cable
options.D: Telephone cable

explanation: Modern IP cameras typically use CAT5/CAT6 Ethernet cables, which can provide both data and power using Power over Ethernet (PoE). Coaxial cable is more associated with traditional analogue systems, and fibre optics normally carry data only, not power.

question: In CCTV operations, what does ANPR stand for?

options.A: Automatic Number Plate Recognition
options.B: Automatic Network Picture Recording
options.C: Advanced Night‑time Picture Resolution
options.D: Analogue Network Protocol Relay

explanation: ANPR stands for Automatic Number Plate Recognition. ANPR systems capture images of vehicle registration plates, use OCR (optical character recognition) to read them, and check them against databases for purposes such as stolen vehicle checks or parking enforcement.

question: What is a key advantage of using cloud storage for CCTV recordings?

options.A: It works without an internet connection
options.B: It removes the need for incident logging
options.C: It guarantees faster frame rates
options.D: Recordings are stored off‑site, providing backup if control room equipment is damaged

explanation: Cloud storage keeps recordings in remote data centres. This provides off‑site backup if local recorders are damaged by fire, theft or flooding. However, it requires internet connectivity and usually involves ongoing subscription costs.

question: An operator needs to monitor a rear fire exit door. The camera only needs to watch that specific doorway, and there is no requirement to track people once they leave. Which type of camera is MOST suitable?

options.A: PTZ camera
options.B: Thermal camera
options.C: Fixed camera
options.D: Wireless camera

explanation: A fixed camera is ideal for a specific, unchanging area such as a door. PTZ cameras are more expensive and better suited to situations where tracking movement or scanning wide areas is required. Thermal and wireless options do not match the basic requirement as directly.

question: You are asked to choose a camera for a busy town‑centre square where operators frequently need to follow suspects and zoom in on faces or number plates. Which camera type is MOST appropriate?

options.A: Fixed dome camera
options.B: PTZ camera
options.C: Thermal camera
options.D: Mini dome camera

explanation: A PTZ camera allows operators to pan across the square, tilt up or down and zoom in on detail. This flexibility makes it ideal for tracking suspects and managing dynamic situations in open public spaces. Fixed and mini domes cannot track movement in the same way.

question: Your organisation is upgrading to a modern CCTV system using only IP cameras and wants high‑resolution recording with easy remote access over the network. Which recording system is MOST suitable?

options.A: Network Video Recorder (NVR)
options.B: Digital Video Recorder (DVR)
options.C: Analogue time‑lapse recorder
options.D: Hybrid DVR/NVR designed mainly for analogue cameras

explanation: An NVR is designed for IP cameras and network‑based recording. It supports higher resolutions and remote access more effectively than a DVR, which is mainly for analogue inputs. A hybrid system is useful for mixed analogue/IP systems, not an all‑IP installation.

question: In a large control room, operators monitor dozens of cameras covering a city centre. What is the MAIN advantage of using a video wall?

options.A: It automatically improves the frame rate of all cameras
options.B: It removes the need for individual monitors
options.C: It eliminates all blind spots in the CCTV system
options.D: It provides a large overview so operators can see many camera images at once

explanation: A video wall gives a big, shared overview of many camera feeds, helping supervisors and operators maintain situational awareness. It does not change camera frame rates or magically remove blind spots; it simply displays the images in a more effective way.

question: A remote park‑and‑ride car park is several kilometres away from the control room. The council wants a high‑capacity, reliable link for multiple high‑resolution cameras, with minimal interference. Which transmission method is MOST appropriate?

options.A: Coaxial cable
options.B: Fibre optic cable
options.C: Wireless link using a basic home router
options.D: Analogue telephone line

explanation: Fibre optic cable is ideal for long distances and high‑bandwidth CCTV transmission. It uses light rather than electrical signals, giving high capacity and resistance to electrical interference. Coaxial and telephone lines are limited over long distances, and a basic wireless router is not suitable for a robust public‑space CCTV link.

question: When reviewing footage for a serious incident, the operator notices that the time stamp on the recording is five minutes behind the actual time. Which routine maintenance task is MOST important to prevent this problem?

options.A: Increasing the frame rate on all cameras
options.B: Cleaning camera lenses more often
options.C: Regularly synchronising system time across cameras and recorders
options.D: Reducing the recording resolution

explanation: Accurate time synchronisation is critical for evidential use of CCTV. All cameras and recorders should be regularly checked and synchronised, often via an NTP server. Frame rate, cleaning and resolution are important for quality, but they do not correct time‑stamp errors.

question: A restricted service yard behind several shops must trigger an alert whenever someone crosses a virtual line into the area outside working hours. Which video analytics feature should be configured?

options.A: Face detection
options.B: Crowd density monitoring
options.C: Object left/removed detection
options.D: Tripwire/line‑crossing detection

explanation: Tripwire or line‑crossing analytics generate an alert when a target crosses a predefined virtual line. This is ideal for detecting unauthorised entry into areas such as service yards. Object left/removed and crowd monitoring are for different types of behaviour.

question: During a live fight in the town centre, the CCTV operator needs to contact police officers on patrol immediately. Which communication method should normally be used FIRST?

options.A: Email
options.B: Radio
options.C: Internal intercom
options.D: Mobile text message

explanation: Radio provides immediate, direct communication with police and partner agencies during incidents. Email and text are too slow for urgent situations, and intercom is usually for internal communication within the premises, not contacting external responders.

question: The NVR is running out of storage before the required 31‑day retention period is reached, but the images still need to be good enough for identifying people. What is usually the BEST adjustment to make first?

options.A: Significantly reduce the camera resolution on all cameras
options.B: Turn off recording on some less important cameras
options.C: Reduce the frame rate slightly while keeping the resolution suitable for identification
options.D: Apply the highest possible compression setting, regardless of image quality

explanation: Lowering the frame rate slightly (for example from 25 fps to a lower but still usable rate) reduces storage while maintaining enough detail for identification. Drastic resolution cuts or extreme compression can seriously harm evidential quality. Turning off cameras reduces coverage and may not be acceptable.

question: An argument between two taxi drivers is captured on CCTV late at night. Police do not attend at the time, but it may be relevant to a later complaint. What should the operator do in the incident logging system?

options.A: Create a time‑stamped entry describing the incident, cameras used and any actions taken
options.B: Do nothing, because no police were called
options.C: Delete the recording immediately to save storage space
options.D: Only make a note if the incident becomes violent

explanation: Incident logs should record all relevant events, not just those where police attend. A time‑stamped entry with details of the incident, cameras and operator actions creates an audit trail and supports any future investigation or complaint.

question: Camera 21 is a PTZ mounted high on a tower, overlooking a dual carriageway. Even at maximum zoom, the operator cannot reliably identify drivers’ faces in vehicles passing 300 metres away. Lighting and focus appear normal. What is the MOST likely limitation in this situation?

options.A: Poor maintenance of the control room monitors
options.B: Incorrect time synchronisation on the NVR
options.C: The camera’s lack of video analytics
options.D: Distance and resolution limits – the camera cannot provide enough detail at that range

explanation: Every camera has limits to what detail it can capture at a given distance. At long ranges, even a PTZ may not provide enough pixels on target for clear facial identification. This is a technical limitation of distance, resolution and lens capability, not a monitor, timing or analytics issue.

question: A facial recognition system linked to the CCTV network generates an alert suggesting a possible match to a person wanted by police. As the CCTV operator, what is the MOST appropriate action?

options.A: Treat the alert as proof of identity and immediately instruct police to arrest the person
options.B: Ignore the alert because facial recognition technology is always inaccurate
options.C: Treat the alert as an indication only, carry out human checks on the images and follow agreed procedures
options.D: Turn off the facial recognition system to avoid any privacy complaints

explanation: Facial recognition is a developing and controversial technology. Alerts should be treated as intelligence, not proof. Operators must verify images, apply human judgement and follow strict procedures and governance. Automatically arresting or ignoring alerts is inappropriate.

question: A key PTZ camera covering a busy bus station suddenly stops responding and shows a black screen. What is the BEST overall response by the operator?

options.A: Report the fault according to procedures, arrange any available alternative coverage, and record all actions in the incident log
options.B: Wait until the end of the shift and then mention it informally to the next operator
options.C: Reboot the NVR repeatedly until the camera starts working again, without telling anyone
options.D: Ignore the problem because other cameras exist elsewhere in the town

explanation: Faults should be reported promptly using the correct procedures. Where possible, temporary measures such as using nearby cameras should be put in place, and all actions must be documented. Delaying, hiding or ignoring the fault fails to manage risk and breaks audit and maintenance requirements.

question: After new 4K monitors are installed very close to each workstation, operators begin to complain of eye strain during long shifts. Which change is MOST likely to reduce this problem while still allowing effective monitoring?

options.A: Reducing all cameras to the lowest possible resolution
options.B: Adjusting the control room layout so monitors are at an appropriate size and viewing distance for operators
options.C: Turning off half of the monitors during quieter periods
options.D: Increasing the brightness of the monitors to make images clearer

explanation: Monitor size, resolution and viewing distance all affect eye strain. Ensuring the screens are at an appropriate distance and ergonomically positioned helps reduce fatigue while maintaining image quality. Simply lowering resolution, switching off screens or increasing brightness does not address the underlying ergonomic issue.

question: On a busy Saturday afternoon, a single operator is monitoring over 80 cameras. Later, management ask why a minor shoplifting incident on one camera was not spotted at the time. Which limitation BEST explains this?

options.A: The cameras were recording at too high a frame rate
options.B: The system was using cloud storage instead of local disks
options.C: The cameras were all fixed rather than PTZ
options.D: Human monitoring limitations – too many cameras and attention/fatigue issues

explanation: There are operational limits to how many cameras one person can effectively monitor. Attention, workload and fatigue mean that minor incidents can be missed, especially with a large number of cameras. This is a human monitoring limitation, not a storage, frame rate or camera type issue. question: In a CCTV control room, what is the MAIN reason for carrying out a formal shift handover between operators?

options.A: To give the outgoing operator time to tidy their desk
options.B: To ensure continuity of operations and transfer of key information
options.C: To check the operator’s personal equipment and uniform
options.D: To reset all cameras to their home positions

explanation: The primary purpose of a shift handover is to ensure continuity of operations and an effective transfer of information between operators. This includes ongoing incidents, intelligence, equipment status, and partner updates. A good handover prevents gaps in monitoring and supports accountability.

question: During handover, which of the following would normally be recorded under equipment status?

options.A: Names of persons currently being monitored
options.B: Details of planned police operations later in the week
options.C: Any camera faults and recording problems noticed during the shift
options.D: Requests from operators for annual leave

explanation: Equipment status in a handover focuses on issues such as camera faults, recording problems, communication failures and scheduled maintenance. These affect the technical capability of the system and must be clearly passed on. Other items, like police operations, are important but belong under intelligence or partner updates.

question: Ten minutes before the end of their shift, a CCTV operator is tracking a suspicious vehicle linked to recent thefts. What is the MOST appropriate action regarding handover?

options.A: Give the incoming operator a clear briefing on the vehicle, its last known location and outstanding actions
options.B: Stop following the vehicle and leave it to the police to update the next operator
options.C: Ignore the incident because it is nearly the end of the shift
options.D: Continue to track the vehicle into their own time without telling the incoming operator

explanation: Ongoing incidents, including persons or vehicles being tracked and any outstanding actions, must be handed over clearly. A verbal briefing ensures the incoming operator understands the current situation and can continue monitoring without gaps. Simply stopping or failing to brief undermines continuity and accountability.

question: A complaint is investigated after a serious incident was missed during a shift change. The review shows the outgoing operator gave a brief “all quiet” comment and left without completing any documentation. Which improvement would have MOST reduced the risk of this failure?

options.A: Allowing the outgoing operator to leave as soon as their shift time ended
options.B: Asking the incoming operator to read previous days’ logs at the end of their shift
options.C: Relying on the police to update the new operator by phone
options.D: Completing a written handover log that both operators sign to confirm the information passed

explanation: A written handover record, acknowledged by both operators, creates a permanent record of what was passed over and clearly transfers responsibility. It supports accountability and can be referred to if something is missed. Relying on informal comments or others (like police) is not a substitute for proper handover documentation.

question: In a CCTV control room, what are Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)?

options.A: Written instructions that set out how normal operations and responses should be carried out
options.B: Informal tips shared between operators during quiet periods
options.C: Criminal law documents that apply to CCTV systems
options.D: Equipment manuals provided by camera manufacturers

explanation: SOPs are written instructions covering normal operations, incident responses, communication and other routine tasks. They provide consistency, support training and demonstrate that staff are working to agreed standards. They are more than informal advice or technical manuals.

question: An operator faces an unusual situation that is not clearly covered by existing SOPs. What is the MOST appropriate way to deal with it?

options.A: Ignore the incident to avoid making a mistake
options.B: Use professional judgement, seek guidance from a supervisor and document the decision taken
options.C: Write a new SOP on the spot and put it in the folder
options.D: Ask a colleague informally and avoid recording any decisions

explanation: When SOPs don’t cover a situation, operators should use their professional judgement but also seek guidance from a supervisor if needed. The decision and reasons should be documented so the situation can be reviewed and SOPs updated later if appropriate. Ignoring incidents or hiding decisions is unprofessional and risky.

question: During a court case, the defence argues that CCTV evidence is unreliable because control room procedures were not followed. Which of the following failures would MOST support this argument?

options.A: The operator wore a different coloured shirt from the usual uniform
options.B: The operator used capital letters when writing their log
options.C: The incident log missed key actions and times that were required by the SOP
options.D: The operator used the phonetic alphabet on the radio

explanation: SOPs often specify how incidents are recorded, including actions, timings and who was informed. Missing key details required by SOPs can undermine the integrity of the evidence and raise doubts about the professionalism of the operation. Uniform colour or using phonetic alphabet would not normally affect evidential value.

question: Which option BEST describes systematic monitoring in a CCTV control room?

options.A: Only watching cameras when someone phones in with a complaint
options.B: Repeatedly staring at a single camera that looks busy
options.C: Randomly picking cameras depending on what interests the operator
options.D: Using planned patrol patterns to ensure regular coverage of cameras and priority areas

explanation: Systematic monitoring means following planned patterns to ensure all relevant areas, especially high‑risk ones, receive regular attention. This helps detect incidents proactively and prevents gaps in coverage. Simply reacting or focusing on one camera is not systematic.

question: Which camera patrol pattern provides simple, systematic coverage but may become predictable to offenders?

options.A: Sequentially viewing camera 1, then 2, then 3, and so on in order
options.B: Only viewing cameras after requests from partners
options.C: Viewing only high‑risk cameras and ignoring the rest
options.D: Choosing cameras at random with no pattern at all

explanation: Sequential patrols (camera 1, then 2, then 3, etc.) are easy to follow and ensure all cameras get some attention. However, if used alone they can become predictable, allowing offenders to time their actions between checks. That’s why systems often mix in priority and random elements.

question: A town centre is quiet during the day but very busy with nightlife at weekends. Which monitoring approach would BEST ensure cameras are used efficiently?

options.A: Using the same fixed patrol pattern at all times of day and night
options.B: Adapting patrol patterns so high‑risk nightlife areas are viewed more often during busy periods
options.C: Turning off cameras in quiet areas completely
options.D: Only responding to calls from the police and not carrying out proactive patrols

explanation: Time‑based monitoring adapts patrols to different times, focusing on rush hour, night‑time economy or special events when risk is higher. This makes better use of limited resources and supports proactive surveillance. A fixed pattern or purely reactive approach is less effective.

question: Which of the following should ALWAYS be included when logging a CCTV incident?

options.A: The operator’s personal opinion of the suspect
options.B: Guesses about what might happen next
options.C: The time, date and camera reference used
options.D: The operator’s feelings about the shift

explanation: Every incident log should record the time, date and camera reference, along with what was observed, actions taken and the outcome. Logs must be factual and based on observations, not opinions or guesses. Personal feelings are irrelevant and unprofessional in an incident record.

question: While completing a paper incident log, an operator realises they wrote the wrong time for when the police were called. What is the MOST appropriate way to correct this?

options.A: Scribble over the wrong time until it cannot be read
options.B: Use correction fluid (e.g. Tipp‑Ex) to hide the original entry
options.C: Tear out the page and start again
options.D: Strike through the incorrect time with a single line, write the correct time and add initials, date and time of the correction

explanation: Incident logs are legal records and must not be altered in a way that hides the original entry. Errors should be crossed out with a single line so they remain readable, then corrected with a note of who made the change and when. This preserves the integrity and audit trail of the record.

question: An operator deals with a disturbance seen on camera but is busy with other tasks and only writes up the log at the end of their eight‑hour shift. Which is the MAIN problem with this approach?

options.A: The record is not contemporaneous and relies on memory rather than being written at the time
options.B: The log is too neat and clearly written
options.C: The operator did not include their personal opinions about those involved
options.D: The police were informed during the incident

explanation: Incident logs should be contemporaneous – written at the time of the incident or as soon as possible while memory is fresh. Waiting until the end of a long shift increases the risk of omissions and inaccuracies. This can weaken the evidential value of the log.

question: Before transmitting on a shared radio channel, what should a CCTV operator do FIRST?

options.A: Press the transmit button and start speaking immediately
options.B: Listen to ensure the channel is clear before transmitting
options.C: Turn the volume down so other operators aren’t disturbed
options.D: Assume others will stop talking when they hear them

explanation: Good radio discipline requires operators to listen first to ensure they do not “talk over” someone else. Once the channel is clear, they should identify themselves and the recipient and then give a clear, concise message. This keeps the radio net efficient and professional.

question: An operator sees a suspicious male loitering near parked vehicles and needs to update the police by radio. What is the BEST way to give the description?

options.A: “There’s a dodgy‑looking bloke hanging around the cars, he looks trouble.”
options.B: “There’s someone I don’t like the look of, I think he’s up to something.”
options.C: “Male, late 20s, dark jacket with hood up, blue jeans, white trainers, currently near the multi‑storey entrance on Camera 12.”
options.D: “There was a man here earlier but he’s probably gone now, I’ll let you know if he comes back.”

explanation: Radio messages should be clear, concise and factual. Descriptions should focus on observable details such as clothing, age, location and behaviour, not personal opinions. This helps responders identify the person quickly and accurately.

question: A CCTV operator must pass a vehicle registration to the police via radio, but the line is noisy. What is the MOST appropriate way to do this?

options.A: Say the registration quickly once and hope it is heard correctly
options.B: Shout the registration repeatedly until someone acknowledges it
options.C: Wait until the end of the shift and email the registration
options.D: Spell out the registration slowly using the standard phonetic alphabet and confirm it has been received correctly

explanation: Using the phonetic alphabet (Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, etc.) improves clarity when passing important details like registrations. Speaking slowly and confirming the message has been understood reduces the chance of errors. Delays or rushed messages can cause confusion.

question: Why is strict access control to the CCTV control room so important?

options.A: To protect CCTV systems and footage, maintain confidentiality and safeguard evidence
options.B: To make it harder for staff to take breaks
options.C: To keep the room quiet for visitors
options.D: To ensure cleaning staff can enter whenever they wish

explanation: The control room contains sensitive systems and images, so access must be limited to authorised persons only. This protects the security of the system, the confidentiality of images and the integrity of evidence. Poor access control can lead to data breaches and tampering.

question: An unknown person tries to follow (“tailgate”) an authorised engineer through the secure control room door. What should the CCTV operator on duty do?

options.A: Ignore it – if they got through the door, they must be allowed in
options.B: Challenge the person politely in line with procedures and verify their authorisation before allowing access
options.C: Hold the door open to be helpful
options.D: Let them in but leave them alone in the room while everyone else is busy

explanation: Operators should be security‑conscious and challenge anyone whose authority to enter is unclear. Tailgating is a common way for unauthorised individuals to gain access. Verification and escorting of visitors are key parts of access control procedures.

question: Under Display Screen Equipment (DSE) guidance, what is the MOST appropriate approach to screen breaks for CCTV operators?

options.A: Take one long break after four hours of continuous viewing
options.B: Only take breaks at meal times
options.C: Take regular, short breaks away from the screens at least every hour
options.D: Avoid breaks completely during busy periods

explanation: DSE guidance recommends regular, short breaks away from display screens – ideally at least once an hour. This helps reduce eye strain, fatigue and musculoskeletal problems. Short, frequent breaks are better than infrequent long ones.

question: Which adjustment is MOST important to help reduce neck strain when setting up a CCTV workstation?

options.A: Turning the radio volume down
options.B: Moving the keyboard as far away as possible
options.C: Sitting on the edge of the chair without back support
options.D: Positioning the main monitor roughly at eye level, directly in front of the operator

explanation: A proper workstation assessment includes positioning the monitor at about eye level and directly in front of the operator, reducing the need to bend or twist the neck. Combined with an adjustable chair and good posture, this supports long‑term comfort. Poor positioning can contribute to neck and back pain.

question: After viewing distressing footage of a serious assault, an operator feels upset and finds it hard to concentrate. What is the MOST appropriate action?

options.A: Inform a supervisor and make use of available support, such as debriefing or counselling
options.B: Keep quiet and hope the feelings go away
options.C: Leave the building without telling anyone
options.D: Watch the footage again to “get used to it”

explanation: CCTV work can involve distressing images, and operators should not struggle alone. Speaking to a supervisor allows support such as debriefing or access to counselling and ensures operational safety. Ignoring stress can affect health, judgement and performance.

question: A CCTV operator has been in the role for six months and reports headaches, eye strain and back pain after each shift. Which combination of actions BEST reflects good practice under DSE and health and safety procedures?

options.A: Continue working as normal but take stronger painkillers
options.B: Request a DSE workstation assessment, adjust chair and monitor appropriately and ensure regular breaks away from the screen
options.C: Stand up all shift with the monitor off to one side
options.D: Turn off some cameras to reduce the amount of viewing required

explanation: DSE regulations and ergonomic principles require employers to assess workstations and provide suitable equipment and guidance. Adjusting the chair, monitor position and work layout, combined with regular screen breaks, helps reduce strain. Painkillers or switching off cameras do not address the root causes and may be unsafe.

question: The fire alarm sounds in the building while you are monitoring live cameras. What is the MOST appropriate action?

options.A: Keep watching the cameras until you can see if there is really a fire
options.B: Ignore the alarm unless smoke is visible in the control room
options.C: Follow the fire evacuation procedures immediately and go to the assembly point
options.D: Silence the alarm if the control room is busy

explanation: In a fire situation, life safety comes first. Operators must follow the building’s fire procedures, which will normally mean leaving immediately by the designated route and reporting to the assembly point. CCTV operations can be resumed once it is safe to do so.

question: During a major town‑centre event, the CCTV monitors suddenly go blank due to a system failure. What should the operator do FIRST?

options.A: Wait to see if the pictures come back on their own
options.B: Switch off all power to the control room
options.C: Panic and leave the control room immediately
options.D: Follow the control room’s system‑failure procedures: report the fault immediately, activate any backup arrangements and start manual logging

explanation: System failures are an emergency for a CCTV control room and should be covered by specific procedures. The operator should report the fault straight away, activate backup systems (such as UPS, generators or alternative monitoring) and use manual logging to record events and actions. This helps maintain critical functions and informs partners.

question: What is the MAIN purpose of quality assurance (QA) activities such as incident audits and log reviews in a CCTV control room?

options.A: To look for reasons to discipline operators
options.B: To maintain standards and improve performance by checking how incidents and logs are handled
options.C: To allow operators to avoid completing paperwork
options.D: To ensure that only the newest camera models are used

explanation: Quality assurance is about maintaining and improving standards, not just blaming individuals. Reviewing incidents, logs and feedback helps identify training needs, procedural issues and good practice. It also demonstrates compliance and builds confidence with partners such as the police and local authorities.
